Device Sampling for Heterogeneous Federated Learning: Theory, Algorithms, and Implementation

Su Wang1, Mengyuan Lee2, Seyyedali Hosseinalipour1, Roberto Morabito3, Mung Chiang1, and Christopher G. Brinton1 1School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University
2College of Information Science and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University
3Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, and Ericsson Research
Email: 1{wang2506, hosseina, chiang, cgb}@purdue.edu, 2mengyuan_lee@zju.edu.cn, 3roberto.morabito@princeton.edu
Abstract

The conventional federated learning (FedL) architecture distributes machine learning (ML) across worker devices by having them train local models that are periodically aggregated by a server. FedL ignores two important characteristics of contemporary wireless networks, however: (i) the network may contain heterogeneous communication/computation resources, while (ii) there may be significant overlaps in devices’ local data distributions. In this work, we develop a novel optimization methodology that jointly accounts for these factors via intelligent device sampling complemented by device-to-device (D2D) offloading. Our optimization aims to select the best combination of sampled nodes and data offloading configuration to maximize FedL training accuracy subject to realistic constraints on the network topology and device capabilities. Theoretical analysis of the D2D offloading subproblem leads to new FedL convergence bounds and an efficient sequential convex optimizer. Using this result, we develop a sampling methodology based on graph convolutional networks (GCNs) which learns the relationship between network attributes, sampled nodes, and resulting offloading that maximizes FedL accuracy. Through evaluation on real-world datasets and network measurements from our IoT testbed, we find that our methodology while sampling less than 5% of all devices outperforms conventional FedL substantially both in terms of trained model accuracy and required resource utilization.

I Introduction

The proliferation of smartphones, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and other devices comprising the Internet of Things (IoT) is causing an exponential rise in data generation and large demands for machine learning (ML) at the edge [1]. For example, sensor and camera modules on self-driving cars produce up to 1.4 terabytes of data per hour [2] with the objective of training ML models for intelligent navigation. The traditional paradigm in ML of centralized training at a server is often not feasible in such environments since (i) transferring these large volumes of data from the devices to the cloud imposes long transfer delays and (ii) users are sometimes unwilling to share their data due to privacy concerns [3].

Federated learning (FedL) is a recently proposed distributed ML technique aiming to overcome these challenges [4, 5].Under FedL, devices train models on their local datasets, typically by means of gradient descent, and a server periodically aggregates the parameters of local models to form a global model. This global model is then transferred back to the devices for the next round of local updates, as depicted in Fig. 1. In conventional FedL, each device processes its own collected data and operates independently within an aggregation period. This will become problematic in terms of upstream device communication and local device processing requirements, however, as its implementations scale to networks consisting of millions of heterogeneous wireless devices [6, 7].

At the same time, device-to-device (D2D) communications that are becoming part of 5G and IoT can enable local offloading of data processing from resource hungry to resource rich devices [8]. Additionally, we can expect that for particular applications, the datasets collected across devices will contain varying degrees of similarity, e.g., images gathered by UAVs conducting surveillance over the same area [9, 10]. Processing similar data distributions at multiple devices adds overhead to FedL and an opportunity for efficiency improvement.

Motivated by this, we develop a novel methodology for smart device sampling with data offloading in FedL. Specifically, we formulate a joint sampling and data offloading optimization problem where devices expected to maximize contribution to model training are sampled for training participation, while devices that are not selected may transfer data to those that are. This data offloading is performed according to estimated data dissimilarities between nodes, which are updated as transfers are observed. We show that our methodology yields superior model performance to conventional FedL while significantly reducing network resource utilization. In our model motivated by paradigms such as fog learning [7, 11, 12], data offloading only occurs among trusted devices; devices that have privacy concerns are exempt from data offloading.

I-A Related Work

To improve the communication efficiency of FedL, recent works have focused on efficient encoding designs to reduce parameter transmission sizes [13, 14], optimizing the frequency of global aggregations [15, 16], and device sampling [17, 18]. Our work falls into the third category. In this regard, most works have assumed a static or uniform device selection strategy, e.g., [16, 11, 19, 20, 12, 5, 21, 22, 17, 18], where the main server chooses a subset of devices either uniformly at random or according to a pre-determined sampling distribution. There is also an emerging line of work on device sampling based on wireless channel characteristics, specifically in cellular networks [23, 24, 25, 26, 27]. By contrast, we develop a sampling technique that adapts to the heterogeneity of device resources and overlaps across local data distributions that are key characteristics of contemporary wireless edge networks. Also, we study device sampling based on the utility of device data distributions. Specifically, when compared to the limited literature on device sampling by each device’s instantaneous contributions to global updates [28], we introduce a novel perspective based on device data similarities. Our methodology exploits the proliferation of D2D communications at the wireless edge [12, 11], to diversify each selected device’s local data via D2D offloading. Our work thus considers the novel problems of sampling and D2D offloading for FedL jointly, and leads to new analytical convergence bounds and algorithms used by implementations.

It is worth mentioning two parallel lines of work in FedL that consider relationships between node data distributions. One is on fairness [29], in which the objective is to train the ML model without biasing the result towards any one device’s distribution, e.g., [30, 31]. Another leverages transfer learning techniques [32] to build models across data parties (e.g., companies or enterprises) that possess partial overlaps [33, 34, 35]. Our work is focused on a fundamentally different objective, i.e., network resource efficiency optimization.

I-B Motivating Toy Example

Consider Fig. 2, wherein five heterogeneous smart cars communicate with an edge server to train an object detection model. Due to limited bandwidth, the server can only exploit 222 out of the 555 cars to conduct FedL training, but needs to train a model representative of the entire dataset within this network. The computational capability of each car, i.e., the number of processed datapoints in one aggregation period, is shown next to itself, and the edge weights in the data similarity graph capture the similarity between the local data of the cars. Rather than using statistical distance metrics [36], which are hard to compute in this distributed scenario, the data similarities could be estimated by commute routes and geographical proximity [37]. Also, in D2D-enabled environments, nodes can exchange small data samples with trusted neighbors to calculate similarities locally and report them to the server.

In Fig. 2, if the server samples the cars with the highest computational capabilities, i.e., A𝐴A and B𝐵B, the sampling is inefficient due to the high data similarity between them. Also, if it samples those with the lowest similarity, i.e., D𝐷D and E𝐸E, the local models will be based on low computational capabilities, which will often result in a low accuracy (and could be catastrophic in this vehicular scenario). Optimal sampling of the cars considering both data similarities and computational capabilities is thus critical to the operation of FedL.

We take this one step further to consider how D2D offloading can lead to augmented local distributions of sampled cars. The node sampling must consider the neighborhoods of different cars and the capability of data offloading in those neighborhoods: D2D is cheaper in terms of resource utilization among those that are close in proximity, for example. The feasible offloading topology in Fig. 2 is represented by the data offloading graph. Given C𝐶C’s high processing capability and data dissimilarity with neighboring cars E𝐸E and D𝐷D, sampling C𝐶C in a D2D-optimized solution can yield a composite of all three cars’ distributions. The purpose of this paper is to model these relationships for a general wireless edge network and optimize the resulting sampling and offloading configurations.

I-C Outline and Summary of Contributions

  • •

    We formulate the joint sampling and D2D offloading optimization problem for maximizing FedL model accuracy subject to realistic network resource constraints (Sec. II).

  • •

    Our theoretical analysis of the offloading subproblem for a fixed sampling strategy yields a new upper bound on the convergence of FedL under an arbitrary data sampling strategy (Sec. III). Using this bound, we derive an efficient sequential convex optimizer for the offloading strategy.

  • •

    We propose a novel ML-based methodology that learns the desired combination of sampling and resulting offloading (Sec. IV). We encapsulate the network structure and offloading scheme into model features and learn a mapping to the sampling strategy that maximizes expected FedL accuracy.

  • •

    We evaluate our methodology through experiments on real-world ML tasks with network parameters from our testbed of wireless IoT devices (Sec. V). Our results demonstrate model accuracies that exceed FedL trained on all devices with significant reductions in processing requirements.

II System and Optimization Model

In this section, we formulate the joint sampling and offloading optimization (Sec. II-D). We first introduce our edge device (Sec. II-A), network (Sec. II-B), and ML (Sec. II-C) models.

II-A Edge Device Model

We consider a set of devices 𝒩={1,⋯,N}𝒩1⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\cdots,N\} connected to a server, and time span t=0,⋯,T𝑡0⋯𝑇t=0,\cdots,T for model training. Each device i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N} possesses a data processing capacity Pi​(t)≥0subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡0P_{i}(t)\geq 0, which limits the number of datapoints it can process for training at time t𝑡t, and a unit data processing cost pi​(t)≥0subscript𝑝𝑖𝑡0p_{i}(t)\geq 0. Intuitively, pi​(t)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}(t), Pi​(t)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡P_{i}(t) are related to the total CPU cycles, memory (RAM), and power available at device i𝑖i [38]. These factors are heterogeneous and time-varying, e.g., as battery power fluctuates and as each device becomes occupied with other tasks. Additionally, for each i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N}, we define Ψi​(t)>0subscriptΨ𝑖𝑡0\Psi_{i}(t)>0 as the data transmit budget, and ψi,j​(t)>0subscript𝜓𝑖𝑗𝑡0\psi_{i,j}(t)>0 as the unit data transmission cost to device j𝑗j. Intuitively, ψi,j​(t)subscript𝜓𝑖𝑗𝑡\psi_{i,j}(t), Ψi​(t)subscriptΨ𝑖𝑡\Psi_{i}(t) are dependent on factors such as the available bandwidth and the channel interference conditions. For example, devices that are closer in proximity would be expected to have lower ψi,j​(t)subscript𝜓𝑖𝑗𝑡\psi_{i,j}(t).

Due to resource constraints, the server selects a set 𝒮⊆𝒩𝒮𝒩\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{N} of devices to participate in FedL training. Some devices i∈𝒮^≜𝒩∖𝒮𝑖^𝒮≜𝒩𝒮i\in\hat{\mathcal{S}}\triangleq\mathcal{N}\setminus\mathcal{S} may be stragglers, i.e., possessing insufficient Pi​(t)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡P_{i}(t) to participate in training, but nonetheless gather data. Different from most works, our methodology will seek to leverage the datasets captured by nodes in the unsampled set 𝒮^^𝒮\hat{\mathcal{S}} via local D2D communications with nodes in the sampling set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}.

We denote the dataset at device i𝑖i for the specific ML application by 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t). 𝒟i​(0)subscript𝒟𝑖0\mathcal{D}_{i}(0) is the initial data at i𝑖i, which evolves as offloading takes place. Henceforth, we use calligraphic font (e.g., 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)) to denote a set, and non-calligraphic (e.g., Di​(t)=|𝒟i​(t)|subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡D_{i}(t)=|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)|) to denote its cardinality. Each data point d∈𝒟i​(t)𝑑subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡d\in\mathcal{D}_{i}(t) is represented as d=(𝐱d,yd)𝑑subscript𝐱𝑑subscript𝑦𝑑d=(\mathbf{x}_{d},y_{d}), where 𝐱d∈ℝMsubscript𝐱𝑑superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbf{x}_{d}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} is a feature vector of M𝑀M features, and yd∈ℝsubscript𝑦𝑑ℝy_{d}\in\mathbb{R} is the target label.

II-B Network Topology and Data Similarity Model

We consider a time-varying network graph G=(𝒩,ℰ​(t))𝐺𝒩ℰ𝑡G=(\mathcal{N},\mathcal{E}(t)), among the set of nodes 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} to represent the available D2D topology. Here, ℰ​(t)ℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}(t) denotes the set of edges or connections between the nodes, where (i,j)∈ℰ​(t)𝑖𝑗ℰ𝑡(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}(t) if node i𝑖i is able/willing to transfer data in D2D mode to node j𝑗j at time t𝑡t, depending on e.g., the trust between the devices, and whether the devices are D2D-enabled. For instance, smart home peripherals can likely transfer data to their owner’s smartphone, while certain smart cars in the vehicular network in Fig. 2 may be unwilling to communicate. We capture these potential D2D relationships using the adjacency matrix 𝐀​(t)=[Ai,j​(t)]1≤i,j≤N𝐀𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑡formulae-sequence1𝑖𝑗𝑁\mathbf{A}(t)=[A_{i,j}(t)]_{1\leq i,j\leq N}, where Ai,j​(t)=1subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑡1A_{i,j}(t)=1 if (i,j)∈ℰ​(t)𝑖𝑗ℰ𝑡(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}(t), and Ai,j​(t)=0subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑡0A_{i,j}(t)=0 otherwise.

We define Φi,j​(t)∈[0,1]subscriptΦ𝑖𝑗𝑡01\Phi_{i,j}(t)\in[0,1] as the fraction of node i𝑖i’s data offloaded to node j𝑗j at time t𝑡t. To optimize this, we are interested in the similarity among local datasets. We define the similarity matrix 𝝀​(t)≜[λi,j​(t)]1≤i,j≤N≜𝝀𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡formulae-sequence1𝑖𝑗𝑁\boldsymbol{\lambda}(t)\triangleq[\lambda_{i,j}(t)]_{1\leq i,j\leq N} among the nodes at time t𝑡t, where 0≤λi,j​(t)≤10subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡10\leq\lambda_{i,j}(t)\leq 1. Higher values of λi,j​(t)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡\lambda_{i,j}(t) imply a higher dataset similarity between nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j, and thus less offloading benefit. In practice, neither the server nor the devices have exact knowledge of the local data distributions. To this end, we consider a probabilistic interpretation of similarity where λi,j​(t)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡\lambda_{i,j}(t) is defined based on the probability that a data point disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} sampled i.i.d from 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t) is “similar” to at least one data point dj∈𝒟j​(t)subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝒟𝑗𝑡d_{j}\in\mathcal{D}_{j}(t). Two datapoints disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} and djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} are considered similar if (i) they have the same label ydi=ydjsubscript𝑦subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑦subscript𝑑𝑗y_{d_{i}}=y_{d_{j}}, and (ii) their feature vectors satisfy ‖𝐱di−𝐱dj‖≤ϵ0normsubscript𝐱subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝐱subscript𝑑𝑗subscriptitalic-ϵ0\|\mathbf{x}_{d_{i}}-\mathbf{x}_{d_{j}}\|\leq\epsilon_{0}, where ϵ0>0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}>0 can be application-specific. Due to device dataset heterogeneity, in general, data similarity will not be symmetric.

For t>0𝑡0t>0, λi,j​(t)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡\lambda_{i,j}(t) is defined from λi,j​(t−1)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗𝑡1\lambda_{i,j}(t-1) according to the offloading behavior, as we will explain in Sec. II-D. Estimates of the initial λi,j​(0)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗0\lambda_{i,j}(0), i.e., before any offloading takes place, can be obtained in several ways that avoid transferring large volumes of data. We assume that device i𝑖i will broadcast a random sample of 𝒟i​(0)subscript𝒟𝑖0\mathcal{D}_{i}(0) to its neighbor j𝑗j, which can then estimate λi,j​(0)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗0\lambda_{i,j}(0) by determining the fraction in this sample that are similar to a d∈𝒟j​(0)𝑑subscript𝒟𝑗0d\in\mathcal{D}_{j}(0). To capture both the node connectivity and data similarity jointly for offloading, we also define the connectivity-similarity matrix 𝚲​(t)=[Λi,j​(t)]𝚲𝑡delimited-[]subscriptΛ𝑖𝑗𝑡\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(t)=[\Lambda_{i,j}(t)], and 𝚲​(t)≜𝝀​(t)∘𝐀​(t)≜𝚲𝑡𝝀𝑡𝐀𝑡\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(t)\triangleq\boldsymbol{\lambda}(t)\circ\mathbf{A}(t), where ∘\circ represents the Hadamard product.

II-C Distributed Machine Learning Model

The learning objective of FedL is to train a global ML model parameterized by a vector 𝐰∈ℝp𝐰superscriptℝ𝑝\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} (e.g., p𝑝p weights in a neural network) using the devices participating in training. Formally, for t∈{0,⋯,T}𝑡0⋯𝑇t\in\{0,\cdots,T\}, each sampled device i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} is concerned with updating its model parameter vector 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) on its local dataset 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t). The local loss at device i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N} is defined as

F​(𝐰i​(t)|𝒟i​(t))=∑d∈𝒟i​(t)f​(𝐰i​(t),𝐱d,yd)Di​(t),𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡subscript𝑑subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡𝑓subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐱𝑑subscript𝑦𝑑subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))=\frac{\sum_{d\in\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)}f(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t),\mathbf{x}_{d},y_{d})}{D_{i}(t)}, (1)

where f​(𝐰i​(t),xd,yd)𝑓subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝑥𝑑subscript𝑦𝑑f(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t),x_{d},y_{d}) denotes the corresponding loss (e.g., squared error for a regression problem, cross-entropy for a classification problem [16]) of each datapoint d∈𝒟i𝑑subscript𝒟𝑖d\in\mathcal{D}_{i}. Each device minimizes its local loss sequentially via gradient descent:

𝐰i​(t)=𝐰i​(t−1)−η​∇F​(𝐰i​(t−1)|𝒟i​(t)),subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)=\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)), (2)

where η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the step size and ∇F​(𝐰i​(t−1)|𝒟i​(t))∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t-1)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)) is the average gradient over the local dataset 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t). With periodicity τ𝜏\tau, the server performs a weighted average of 𝐰i​(k​τ)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau), i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}:

𝐰𝒮​(k​τ)=∑i∈𝒮Δi​(k​τ)​𝐰i​(k​τ)∑i∈𝒮Δi​(k​τ),subscript𝐰𝒮𝑘𝜏subscript𝑖𝒮subscriptΔ𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝑖𝒮subscriptΔ𝑖𝑘𝜏\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(k\tau)=\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\Delta_{i}(k\tau)\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau)}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\Delta_{i}(k\tau)}, (3)

where k𝑘k denotes the k𝑘k-th aggregation, k∈{1,⋯,K}𝑘1⋯𝐾k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, K=⌈T/τ⌉𝐾𝑇𝜏K=\lceil T/\tau\rceil, and Δi​(k​τ)≜∑t=(k−1)​τ+1k​τDi​(t)≜subscriptΔ𝑖𝑘𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘1𝜏1𝑘𝜏subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡\Delta_{i}(k\tau)\triangleq\sum_{t=(k-1)\tau+1}^{k\tau}D_{i}(t) denotes the total data located at node i𝑖i between k−1𝑘1k-1 and k𝑘k. The server then synchronizes the sampled devices: 𝐰i​(k​τ)←𝐰𝒮​(k​τ)←subscript𝐰𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝐰𝒮𝑘𝜏\mathbf{w}_{i}(k\tau)\leftarrow\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(k\tau), ∀i∈𝒮for-all𝑖𝒮\forall i\in\mathcal{S}.

Since we are concerned with the performance of the global parameter 𝐰𝒮subscript𝐰𝒮\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}, we define 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t) as the weighted average of 𝐰i​(t)subscript𝐰𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) as in (3) for each time t𝑡t, though it is only computed at the server when t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau. The global loss that we seek to optimize considers the loss over all the datapoints in the network:

F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t))=∑i∈𝒩Di​(t)​F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟i​(t))D𝒩​(t),𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡\displaystyle F\left(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)\right)=\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}D_{i}(t)F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))}{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)}, (4)

where 𝒟𝒩​(t)subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t) denotes the multiset of the datasets of all the devices at time t𝑡t, and D𝒩​(t)≜∑i∈𝒩Di​(t)≜subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}D_{i}(t).

II-D Joint Sampling and Offloading Optimization

The goal of our optimization is to select (i) the subset of devices 𝒮⋆superscript𝒮⋆\mathcal{S}^{\star} to sample from a total budget of S𝑆S and (ii) the offloading ratios Φi,j⋆​(t)subscriptsuperscriptΦ⋆𝑖𝑗𝑡\Phi^{\star}_{i,j}(t) between the devices to minimize the loss associated with 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t). We consider a time average for the objective, as devices may rely on intermediate aggregations for real-time inferences. For the variables, we define the binary vector 𝐱≜(x1,⋯,xN)≜𝐱subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑁\mathbf{x}\triangleq(x_{1},\cdots,x_{N}) to represent device sampling status, i.e., if i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} then xi=1subscript𝑥𝑖1x_{i}=1, otherwise xi=0subscript𝑥𝑖0x_{i}=0, and matrix 𝚽​(t)≜[Φi,j​(t)]1≤i,j≤N≜𝚽𝑡subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptΦ𝑖𝑗𝑡formulae-sequence1𝑖𝑗𝑁\boldsymbol{\Phi}(t)\triangleq[\Phi_{i,j}(t)]_{1\leq i,j\leq N} to represent the offloading ratios at time t𝑡t. The resulting optimization problem 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} is as follows:

(𝓟):minimize𝐱,{𝚽​(t)}t=1T​1T​∑t=1TF​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t)):𝓟𝐱superscriptsubscript𝚽𝑡𝑡1𝑇minimize1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\displaystyle(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}):\leavevmode\nobreak\ \underset{\mathbf{x},\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}(t)\}_{t=1}^{T}}{\textrm{minimize}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)) (5)

(17)

The data at sampled devices, i.e., Di​(t)subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{i}(t) for i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}, changes over time in (6) based on the total received data Ri​(t)subscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}(t) for device i𝑖i. Ri​(t)subscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}(t) is determined in (7) by scaling the data transmissions from k∈𝒮^𝑘^𝒮k\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} to device i𝑖i according to the similarity. In response to the data offloading, the connectivity-similarity matrix is updated in (8). Together, (7) and (8) capture similarity-aware D2D offloading, which we explain further in the following paragraph. Next, (9)-(11) ensure that our D2D offloading solution adheres to device receive capacities θi​(t)subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}(t), data processing limits Pi​(t)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡P_{i}(t), and D2D limits Ψi​(t)subscriptΨ𝑖𝑡\Psi_{i}(t). (12) ensures total offloaded data by device k𝑘k does not exceed its local dataset size. Through (13)-(15), offloading only occurs between single-hop D2D neighbors from k∈𝒮^𝑘^𝒮k\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} to i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}. (16) maintains compliance with the desired sampling size, i.e., |𝒮⋆|=Ssuperscript𝒮⋆𝑆|\mathcal{S}^{\star}|=S.

Similarity-aware D2D offloading: The amount of raw data device i𝑖i receives from k𝑘k is Φk,i​(t)​Dk​(t−1)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)D_{k}(t-1). Ideally, device i𝑖i will receive data that is dissimilar to 𝒟i​(0)subscript𝒟𝑖0\mathcal{D}_{i}(0). However, neither i𝑖i nor k𝑘k have full knowledge of each others’ datasets in this distributed scenario (nor does the server). Therefore, data offloading in 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} is conducted through an i.i.d. selection of Φk,i​(t)​Dk​(t−1)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)D_{k}(t-1) data points from k𝑘k to send to i𝑖i. The estimated overlapping data that arrives at i𝑖i is Φk,i​(t)​Dk​(t−1)​Λk,i​(t−1)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡1subscriptΛ𝑘𝑖𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)D_{k}(t-1)\Lambda_{k,i}(t-1), and the resulting useful data is Φk,i​(t)​Dk​(t−1)​(1−Λk,i​(t−1))subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘𝑡11subscriptΛ𝑘𝑖𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)D_{k}(t-1)(1-\Lambda_{k,i}(t-1)). We therefore adjust Λk,i​(t)subscriptΛ𝑘𝑖𝑡\Lambda_{k,i}(t) by the effective fraction of data Φk,i​(t)​(1−Λk,i​(t−1))subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡1subscriptΛ𝑘𝑖𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)(1-\Lambda_{k,i}(t-1)) offloaded from k𝑘k to i𝑖i, resulting in (8). In particular, when k𝑘k transfers all of its data to i𝑖i (i.e., Φk,i​(t)=1subscriptΦ𝑘𝑖𝑡1\Phi_{k,i}(t)=1), Λk,i​(t)subscriptΛ𝑘𝑖𝑡\Lambda_{k,i}(t) becomes 1, preventing further data offloading from k𝑘k to i𝑖i according to (7). Imposing these constraints promotes data diversity among the sampled nodes through offloading.

Solution overview: Problem 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} faces two major challenges: (i) it requires a concrete model of the loss function with respect to the datasets, which is, in general, intractable for deep learning models [39], and (ii) even if the loss function is known, the coupled sampling and offloading procedures make this problem an NP-hard mixed integer programming problem. To overcome this, we will first consider the offloading subproblem for a fixed sampling strategy, and develop a sequential convex programming method to solve it in Sec. III. Then, we will integrate this into a graph convolutional network (GCN)-based methodology that learns the relationship between the network properties, sampling strategy (with its corresponding offloading), and the resulting FedL model accuracy in Sec. IV. An overall flowchart of our methodology is given in Fig. 3.

III Developing the Offloading Optimizer

In this section, we study the offloading optimization subproblem of 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}. Our theoretical analysis of (5) under common assumptions will yield an efficient approximation of the objective in terms of the offloading variables (Sec. III-B). We will then develop our solver for the resulting optimization (Sec. III-C).

III-A Definitions and Assumptions

To aid our theoretical analysis of FedL, similar to [16], we will consider a hypothetical ML training process that has access to the entire dataset 𝒟𝒩​(t)subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t) at each time instance. The parameter vector 𝐯k​(t)subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) for this centralized model is trained as follows: (i) at each global aggregation t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau, 𝐯k​(t)subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) is synchronized with 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t), i.e., 𝐯k​(t)←𝐰𝒮​(t)←subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)\leftarrow\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t), and (ii) in-between global aggregation periods, 𝐯k​(t)subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) is trained based on gradient descent iterations to minimize the global loss F​(𝐯k​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t))𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐯𝑘𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡F(\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)).

Definition 1 (Difference between sampled and unsampled gradients).

We define the instantaneous difference between ∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t))∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)), the gradient with respect to the full dataset across the network, and ∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟𝒮​(t))∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝒮𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)), the gradient with respect to the sampled dataset, as:

ζ​(𝐰𝒮​(t))≜G𝒮​(t)D𝒮​(t)−∑i∈𝒩Di​(t)​∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟i​(t))D𝒩​(t),≜𝜁subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝐺𝒮𝑡subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡\displaystyle\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t))\triangleq\frac{G_{\mathcal{S}}(t)}{D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)}-\frac{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}D_{i}(t)\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))}{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)}, (18)

where G𝒮​(t)≜∑i∈𝒮Di​(t)​∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟i​(t))≜subscript𝐺𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡G_{\mathcal{S}}(t)\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}D_{i}(t)\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)) is the scaled sum of gradients on the sampled datasets, and D𝒮​(t)=∑i∈𝒮Di​(t)subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}D_{i}(t) is the total data across the sampled devices.

Definition 2 (Difference between sampled and unsampled gradients).

We define δi​(t)subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡\delta_{i}(t) as the upper bound between the gradient computed on 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t) for i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} and 𝒟𝒩​(t)subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t) at time t𝑡t:

∥∇F(𝐰𝒮(t)|𝒟i(t))−∇F(𝐰𝒮(t)|𝒟𝒩(t))−ζ(𝐰𝒮(t))∥≤δi(t).\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t))-\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t))\|\leq\delta_{i}(t). (19)

We also make the following standard assumptions [16, 12] on the loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}) for the ML model being trained:

Assumption 1.

We assume F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}) is convex with respect to 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, L-Lipschitz, i.e., ‖F​(𝐰)−F​(𝐰′)‖≤L​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖norm𝐹𝐰𝐹superscript𝐰′𝐿norm𝐰superscript𝐰′\|F(\mathbf{w})-F(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|, and β𝛽\beta-smooth, i.e., ‖∇F​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰′)‖≤β​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖norm∇𝐹𝐰∇𝐹superscript𝐰′𝛽norm𝐰superscript𝐰′\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\prime})\|\leq\beta\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{w}^{\prime}\|, ∀𝐰,𝐰′for-all𝐰superscript𝐰′\forall\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{\prime}.

Despite these assumptions, we will show in Sec. V that our results still obtain significant improvements in practice for neural networks which do not obey the above assumptions.

III-B Upper Bound on Convergence

For convergence analysis, we assume that devices only offload the same data once, and assume that recipient nodes always keep received data. This must be done to ensure that the optimal global model parameters remain constant throughout time. The following theorem gives an upper bound on the difference between the parameters of sampled FedL and those from the centralized learning, i.e., ‖𝐰𝒮​(t)−𝐯k​(t)‖normsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡\|\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)-\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)\|, over time:

Theorem 1 (Upper bound on the difference between sampled FedL and centralized learning).

Assuming η≤β−1𝜂superscript𝛽1\eta\leq{\beta}^{-1}, the upper-bound on the difference between 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t) and 𝐯k​(t)subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) within the local update period before the k𝑘k-th global aggregation, t∈{(k−1)​τ+1,…,k​τ}𝑡𝑘1𝜏1…𝑘𝜏t\in\{(k-1)\tau+1,...,k\tau\}, is given by:

‖𝐰𝒮​(t)−𝐯k​(t)‖≤1β​∑y=(k−1)​τ+1t(Υ​(y,k)+‖ζ​(𝐰𝒮​(y−1))‖),normsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝐯𝑘𝑡1𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘1𝜏1𝑡Υ𝑦𝑘norm𝜁subscript𝐰𝒮𝑦1\|\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)-\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)\|\leq\frac{1}{\beta}\sum_{y=(k-1)\tau+1}^{t}\bigg{(}\Upsilon(y,k)+\|\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(y-1))\|\bigg{)}, (20)

where Υ​(y,k)≜δ𝒮​(y)​(2y−1−(k−1)​τ−1)≜Υ𝑦𝑘subscript𝛿𝒮𝑦superscript2𝑦1𝑘1𝜏1\Upsilon(y,k)\triangleq\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(y)(2^{y-1-(k-1)\tau}-1), and

δ𝒮​(t)≜(∑i∈𝒮Di​(t)​δi​(t))​(∑i∈𝒮Di​(t))−1.≜subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡1\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t)\triangleq\left({\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}D_{i}(t)\delta_{i}(t)}\right)\left({\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}D_{i}(t)}\right)^{-1}. (21)
Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Through δ𝒮​(t)subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t), Theorem 1 establishes a relationship between the difference in model parameters and the datapoints Di​(t)subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{i}(t) in the sampled set i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}. Using this, we obtain an upper bound on the difference between our 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t) and the global minimizer of model loss 𝐰∗​(t)=arg​min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰|𝒟𝒩​(t))superscript𝐰𝑡subscriptargmin𝐰𝐹conditional𝐰subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}(t)=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\mathbf{w}}F(\mathbf{w}|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)):

Corollary 1 (Upper bound on the difference between sampled FedL and the optimal).

The difference of the loss induced by 𝐰𝒮​(t)subscript𝐰𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t) compared to the loss induced by 𝐰∗​(t)superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{*}(t) for t∈{(k−1)​τ,⋯,k​τ−1}𝑡𝑘1𝜏⋯𝑘𝜏1t\in\{(k-1)\tau,\cdots,k\tau-1\}, is given by:

F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t))−F​(𝐰∗​(t)|𝒟𝒩​(t))≤𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡𝐹conditionalsuperscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝒟𝒩𝑡absent\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t))-F(\mathbf{w}^{*}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t))\leq (22)
g​(Υ^​(K^))≜(t​ξ​η​(1−β​η2)−(K^+1)​Lβ​ϵ2​Υ^​(K^))−1,≜𝑔^Υ^𝐾superscript𝑡𝜉𝜂1𝛽𝜂2^𝐾1𝐿𝛽superscriptitalic-ϵ2^Υ^𝐾1\displaystyle g(\hat{\Upsilon}(\hat{K}))\triangleq\left(t\xi\eta\left(1-\frac{\beta\eta}{2}\right)-\frac{(\hat{K}+1)L}{\beta\epsilon^{2}}\hat{\Upsilon}(\hat{K})\right)^{-1},

where Υ^​(K^)≜∑y=(K^−1)​τ+1K^​τ(Υ​(K^,y)+‖ζ​(𝐰𝒮​(y−1))‖)≜^Υ^𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑦^𝐾1𝜏1^𝐾𝜏Υ^𝐾𝑦norm𝜁subscript𝐰𝒮𝑦1\hat{\Upsilon}(\hat{K})\triangleq\sum_{y=(\hat{K}-1)\tau+1}^{\hat{K}\tau}\left(\Upsilon(\hat{K},y)+\|\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(y-1))\|\right), K^=⌊t/τ⌋^𝐾𝑡𝜏\hat{K}=\lfloor t/\tau\rfloor, and ξ=mink⁡1‖𝐯k​((k−1)​τ)−𝐰∗​(t)‖2𝜉subscript𝑘1superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑘𝑘1𝜏superscript𝐰𝑡2\xi=\min_{k}\frac{1}{{\|\mathbf{v}_{k}((k-1)\tau)-\mathbf{w}^{*}(t)\|}^{2}}.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

As our ultimate goal is an expression of (5) in terms of the data 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t) at each node, we consider the relationship between g​(Υ^​(K^))𝑔^Υ^𝐾g(\hat{\Upsilon}({\hat{K}})) and 𝒟i​(t)subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t), which is clearly non-convex through Υ^​(K^)^Υ^𝐾\hat{\Upsilon}({\hat{K}}). Since Υ^​(K^)≪1much-less-than^Υ^𝐾1\hat{\Upsilon}(\hat{K})\ll 1 (see Appendix B), (22) can be approximated using the first two terms of its Taylor series:

g​(Υ^)≈1t​ξ​η​(1−η​β2)+(K^+1)​Lβ​ϵ2​(t​ξ​η​(1−η​β2))2​Υ^.𝑔^Υ1𝑡𝜉𝜂1𝜂𝛽2^𝐾1𝐿𝛽superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝑡𝜉𝜂1𝜂𝛽22^Υ\displaystyle g(\hat{\Upsilon})\approx\frac{1}{t\xi\eta(1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2})}+\frac{{(\hat{K}+1)L}}{\beta\epsilon^{2}\left(t\xi\eta(1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2})\right)^{2}}\hat{\Upsilon}. (23)

At each time instant, the first term in the right hand side (RHS) of (23) is a constant. Thus, under this approximation, the RHS of (22) becomes proportional to Υ^^Υ\hat{\Upsilon}, which is in turn a function of δ𝒮​(t)subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t). The final step is to bound the expression for δi​(t)subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡\delta_{i}(t), and thus their weighted sum δ𝒮​(t)subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t), in terms of the Di​(t)subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{i}(t), ∀i∈𝒮for-all𝑖𝒮\forall i\in\mathcal{S}.

The above proposition relates each δi​(t)subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡\delta_{i}(t) to the number of instantaneous data points available at device i𝑖i.

III-C Offloading as a Sequential Convex Optimization

Using the result of (23) to replace the RHS of (22) implies that the objective function in (5) is proportional to 1T​∑t=1Tδ𝒮​(t)1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t), where δ𝒮​(t)subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t) is defined in (21) as a sum-of-ratios of δi​(t)subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡\delta_{i}(t). Considering 1T​∑t=1Tδ𝒮​(t)1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t) as the objective in problem 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} yields the sum-of-ratios problem in fractional programming [40]. The scale of existing solvers for the sum-of-ratios fractional programming problem (e.g. [41]) are on the order of ten ratios, which corresponds to ten devices in our case. Contemporary large-scale networks that may have hundreds of edge devices [1] therefore cannot be solved accurately or in a time-sensitive manner. Motivated by the above fact, we approximate δ𝒮​(t)≈1S​∑i∈𝒮δi​(t)subscript𝛿𝒮𝑡1𝑆subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝛿𝑖𝑡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t)\approx\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\delta_{i}(t). Using this with (24), we obtain the following approximation for (5):

1T​∑t=1T(D𝒩​(t)−D𝒮​(t)D𝒩​(t))​∇F​(t)¯⏟(a)+1|𝒮|​∑i∈𝒮γDi​(t)⏟(b),1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript⏟subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡¯∇𝐹𝑡𝑎1𝒮subscript𝑖𝒮subscript⏟𝛾subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑏\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\underbrace{\left(\frac{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)-D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)}{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)}\right)\overline{\nabla F(t)}}_{(a)}+\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\underbrace{\frac{\gamma}{\sqrt{D_{i}(t)}}}_{(b)}, (26)

where term (a)𝑎(a) is due to sampling and term (b)𝑏(b) is the statistical error from the central limit theorem. Thus, for a known binary vector 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} (i.e., a known 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}) that satisfies (16), we arrive at the following optimization problem for the D2D data offloading:

(𝓟D):min{𝚽​(t)}t=1T(26)\displaystyle(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D}):\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \underset{\{\boldsymbol{\Phi}(t)\}_{t=1}^{T}}{\min}\eqref{eq:obj_temp} s.t.​(6)−(15),(17).s.t.61517\displaystyle\textrm{s.t.}\leavevmode\nobreak\ (6)-(15),(17).

Since the number of datapoints at the unsampled devices is fixed for all time, D𝒩​(t)subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡D_{\mathcal{N}}(t) can be expressed as D𝒮​(t)+D𝒮^subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝐷^𝒮D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)+D_{\hat{\mathcal{S}}}, where D𝒮^=∑i∈𝒮^Disubscript𝐷^𝒮subscript𝑖^𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖D_{\hat{\mathcal{S}}}=\sum_{i\in\hat{\mathcal{S}}}D_{i} is a constant. Consequently, both the coefficient of ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)} in term (a)𝑎(a) and the entirety of term (b)𝑏(b) in (26) are decreasing functions of the quantity of data Di​(t)subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡D_{i}(t) at sampled devices i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}. Furthermore, given ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)}, through (6) and (7), both terms (a)𝑎(a) and (b)𝑏(b) are convex with respect to the offloading variables in Problem 𝓟Dsubscript𝓟𝐷\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D}. The only remaining challenge is then to obtain ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)}, which we consider next.

Sequential gradient approximation: Obtaining ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)} requires the knowledge of real-time gradients, ∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟i​(t))∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)), ∀i∈𝒮for-all𝑖𝒮\forall i\in\mathcal{S}, which are unknown a priori. Furthermore, the gradients of the devices are only observed at the global aggregation time instances t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau. Motivated by this, we approximate ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla{{F}(t)}} for t∈{k​τ+1,⋯,(k+1)​τ}𝑡𝑘𝜏1⋯𝑘1𝜏t\in\{k\tau+1,\cdots,(k+1)\tau\}, k∈{1,⋯,K}𝑘1⋯𝐾k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, using the gradients observed at the most recent global aggregation, i.e., ∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(k​τ)|𝒟i​(k​τ))∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑘𝜏subscript𝒟𝑖𝑘𝜏\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(k\tau)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(k\tau)), i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} on which we perform a sequence of corrective approximations. Specifically, since the average loss F𝐹F is convex, ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)} is expected to decrease over time. We assume that this decrease occurs linearly and approximate the real-time gradient using the previously observed gradient at the server as ∇F​(t)¯≈∇F​(k​τ)¯/αk+1t−k​τ¯∇𝐹𝑡¯∇𝐹𝑘𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑡𝑘𝜏𝑘1\overline{\nabla F(t)}\approx\overline{\nabla F(k\tau)}/{\alpha^{t-k\tau}_{k+1}}, t∈{k​τ+1,⋯,(k+1)​τ}𝑡𝑘𝜏1⋯𝑘1𝜏t\in\{k\tau+1,\cdots,(k+1)\tau\}, ∀k∈{1,⋯,K}for-all𝑘1⋯𝐾\forall k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, where the scaling factor αk+1>1subscript𝛼𝑘11\alpha_{k+1}>1 is re-adjusted after every global aggregation k𝑘k. Through the re-adjustment procedure, the server receives the gradients and computes the scaling factor for the each aggregation period as αk+1=∇F​((k−1)​τ)¯/∇F​(k​τ)¯τsubscript𝛼𝑘1𝜏¯∇𝐹𝑘1𝜏¯∇𝐹𝑘𝜏\alpha_{k+1}=\sqrt[\tau]{\overline{\nabla F((k-1)\tau)}/\overline{\nabla F(k\tau)}}.

Given the aforementioned characteristics of terms (a)𝑎(a) and (b)𝑏(b) in (26), our proposed iterative approximation of ∇F​(t)¯¯∇𝐹𝑡\overline{\nabla F(t)}, and the fact that the constraints of 𝓟Dsubscript𝓟𝐷\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D} are all affine at each time instance, we can solve this problem as a sequence of convex optimization problems over time. For this, we employ the CVXPY convex optimization software [42].

IV Smart Device Sampling with D2D Offloading

We now turn to the sampling decisions in problem 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}, which must be coupled with the offloading solution to 𝓟Dsubscript𝓟𝐷\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D}. After explaining the rationale for our GCN-based approach (Sec. IV-A), we will detail our training procedure encoding the network characteristics (Sec. IV-B). Finally, we will develop an iterative procedure for selecting the sample set (Sec. IV-C).

IV-A Rationale and Overview of GCN Sampling Approach

Sampling the optimal subset of nodes from a resource-constrained network to maximize a utility function (in our case, minimizing the ML loss) has some similarity to 0-1 knapsack problem [43]. In this combinatorial optimization problem, a set of weights and values for n𝑛n items are given, where each item can be either added or left out to maximize the value of the items within the knapsack subject to a weight capacity. Analogously, our sampling problem aims to maximize FedL accuracy while adhering to a sampling budget S=∑i∈𝒩xi𝑆subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝑥𝑖S=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}x_{i}. Strategies for the knapsack problem become unsuitable here because the value that each device provides to FedL is difficult to quantify: it depends on the ML loss function, the gradient descent procedure, and the D2D relationships from Sec. III.

To address these complexities, we propose a (separate) ML technique to model the relationship between network characteristics, the sampling set, and the resulting FedL model quality. Specifically, we develop a sampling technique based on active filtering of a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) [44, 45]. In a GCN, the learning procedure consists of sequentially feeding an input (the network graph) through a series of graph convolution [46] layers, which generalize the traditional convolution operation into non-Euclidean spaces and thus captures connections among nodes in different neighborhoods.

Our methodology is depicted in Fig. 4. GCNs excel at graph-based classification tasks, as they learn over the intrinsic graph structure. However, GCNs by themselves have performance issues when there are multiple good candidates for the classification problem [47]. This holds for our large-scale network scenario, as many high performing sets of sampling candidates can be expected. The data offloading scheme adds another important dimension: a sampled node i𝑖i may perform poorly when considered in isolation, but it may have high processing capacities Pi​(t)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡P_{i}(t) and be connected to unsampled nodes j∈𝒮^𝑗^𝒮j\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} with large quantities of local data and high transfer limits Ψj,i​(t)subscriptΨ𝑗𝑖𝑡\Psi_{j,i}(t). We address these issues by (i) incorporating the solution from Sec. III into the GCN training procedure, and (ii) proposing sampling GCN-branch, a network-based post-processing technique that maps the GCN output to a sampling set by considering the underlying connectivity-similarity matrix.

IV-B GCN Architecture and Training Procedure

We consider a GCN function H​(𝝅,𝐀~)𝐻𝝅~𝐀H(\boldsymbol{\pi},\tilde{\mathbf{A}}) with two inputs: (i) 𝝅∈ℝN×U𝝅superscriptℝ𝑁𝑈\boldsymbol{\pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times U}, a matrix of U𝑈U node features, and (ii) 𝐀~∈ℝN×N~𝐀superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁\mathbf{\tilde{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N}, the augmented connectivity-similarity matrix. The feature vector for each node i𝑖i is defined as 𝝅i≜[Di​(0),Pi​(0),pi​(0),θi​(0)]≜subscript𝝅𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖0subscript𝑃𝑖0subscript𝑝𝑖0subscript𝜃𝑖0\boldsymbol{\pi}_{i}\triangleq[D_{i}(0),P_{i}(0),p_{i}(0),\theta_{i}(0)], forming the rows of 𝝅𝝅\boldsymbol{\pi}, and the augmented connectivity-similarity matrix is defined as 𝐀~≜𝚲​(𝟎)+𝐈N≜~𝐀𝚲0subscript𝐈𝑁\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\triangleq\boldsymbol{{\Lambda}(0)}+\mathbf{I}_{N}, where 𝐈Nsubscript𝐈𝑁\mathbf{I}_{N} denotes the identity matrix [46]. H𝐻H consists of two graph convolutional layers separated by a rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation layer [44], as depicted in Fig. 4. The outputs of each layer are defined as:

𝐇(l)≜σ​(𝐃~−12​𝐀~​𝐃~−12​𝐇(l−1)​𝐐(l)),l∈{1,2},formulae-sequence≜superscript𝐇𝑙𝜎superscript~𝐃12~𝐀superscript~𝐃12superscript𝐇𝑙1superscript𝐐𝑙𝑙12\mathbf{H}^{(l)}\triangleq\sigma\left(\tilde{\mathbf{D}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\tilde{\mathbf{D}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\mathbf{H}^{(l-1)}\mathbf{Q}^{(l)}\right),\leavevmode\nobreak\ l\in\{1,2\},\vspace{-1mm} (27)

where 𝐃~~𝐃\tilde{\mathbf{D}} is the degree matrix of 𝐀~~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{A}}, 𝐐(l)superscript𝐐𝑙\mathbf{Q}^{(l)} denotes the trainable weights for the l𝑙l-th layer, and σ𝜎\sigma represents ReLU activation. Note that 𝐇(0)=𝝅superscript𝐇0𝝅\mathbf{H}^{(0)}=\boldsymbol{\pi}, 𝐐(1)∈ℝU×Osuperscript𝐐1superscriptℝ𝑈𝑂\mathbf{Q}^{(1)}\in\mathbb{R}^{U\times O}, and 𝐐(2)∈ℝO×1superscript𝐐2superscriptℝ𝑂1\mathbf{Q}^{(2)}\in\mathbb{R}^{O\times 1}, where O𝑂O is the dimension of the second layer. Finally, log-softmax activation is applied to 𝐇(2)∈ℝNsuperscript𝐇2superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{H}^{(2)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} to convert the results into a vector of probabilities, i.e., 𝚪∈[0,1]N𝚪superscript01𝑁\boldsymbol{\Gamma}\in[0,1]^{N}, representing the likelihood of each node belonging to the sampled set.

GCN training procedure: To train the GCN weights, we generate a set of sample network and node data realizations e=1,⋯,E𝑒1⋯𝐸e=1,\cdots,E with the properties from Sec. II-A&II-B. For each realization, we calculate the matrices 𝝅esubscript𝝅𝑒\boldsymbol{\pi}_{e} and 𝐀~esubscript~𝐀𝑒\mathbf{\tilde{A}}_{e} corresponding to the inputs of the GCN. Then, for each candidate sampling allocation 𝐱es=[(xes)i]1≤i≤Nsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑠𝑒subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑠𝑒𝑖1𝑖𝑁\mathbf{x}^{s}_{e}=[({x}^{s}_{e})_{i}]_{1\leq i\leq N} (with ∑i(xes)i=Ssubscript𝑖subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑠𝑒𝑖𝑆\sum_{i}({x}^{s}_{e})_{i}=S), we solve 𝓟Dsubscript𝓟𝐷\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D} from Sec. III to obtain the offloading scheme, and then determine the loss of FedL resulting from model training and D2D offloading. Among these, we choose the 𝐱e⋆subscriptsuperscript𝐱⋆𝑒\mathbf{x}^{\star}_{e} that yields the smallest objective to be the target GCN output. The collection of [(𝝅e,𝑨~e,𝐱e⋆)]e=1Esuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝝅𝑒subscriptbold-~𝑨𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝐱⋆𝑒𝑒1𝐸[(\boldsymbol{\pi}_{e},\boldsymbol{\tilde{A}}_{e},\mathbf{x}^{\star}_{e})]_{e=1}^{E} form the training samples for the GCN.

As the number of devices N𝑁N increases, the number of choices that will be considered for the sampled set increases combinatorially as (NS)binomial𝑁𝑆\binom{N}{S}. An advantage of this GCN procedure is that it is network-size independent: once trained on a set of realizations for tolerable-sized values of N𝑁N, the graph convolutional layer weights 𝐐(l)superscript𝐐𝑙\mathbf{Q}^{(l)}, l∈{1,2}𝑙12l\in\{1,2\}, can be applied to the desired network of arbitrary size N𝑁N. Our obtained performance results in Sec. V verify this experimentally.

IV-C Offloading-Aware Smart Device Sampling

Given any network graph, our procedure must solve the sampling problem at the point of FedL initialization, i.e., t=0𝑡0t=0. With the trained GCN in hand, we obtain 𝝅𝝅\boldsymbol{\pi} and 𝐀~~𝐀\tilde{\mathbf{A}} for the target network and calculate 𝚪=H​(𝝅,𝐀~)𝚪𝐻𝝅~𝐀\boldsymbol{\Gamma}=H(\boldsymbol{\pi},\tilde{\mathbf{A}}), 𝚪=[Γi]1≤i≤N𝚪subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptΓ𝑖1𝑖𝑁\boldsymbol{\Gamma}=[\Gamma_{i}]_{1\leq i\leq N}. Given this output, our sampling GCN-branch algorithm populates the set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} as follows. Let 𝒩p⊂𝒩subscript𝒩𝑝𝒩\mathcal{N}_{p}\subset\mathcal{N} be the subset of nodes in the 98th percentile of initial data quantity. Starting with 𝒮=∅𝒮\mathcal{S}=\varnothing, the first node is added according to S=S∪{s1}𝑆𝑆subscript𝑠1S=S\cup\{s_{1}\}, where s1=arg​maxi∈𝒩p⁡Γisubscript𝑠1subscriptargmax𝑖subscript𝒩𝑝subscriptΓ𝑖s_{1}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{p}}\Gamma_{i}. In this way, the first node added is the device with highest GCN probability among the largest data generation nodes. To choose subsequent sampled nodes, the algorithm performs a recursive branch-based search on the initial connectivity-similarity matrix 𝚲​(0)𝚲0\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(0) for nodes with the highest sampling probabilities and the least aggregate data similarity to the previously sampled nodes. Formally, we choose the n𝑛n-th node addition as 𝒮=𝒮∪{sn}𝒮𝒮subscript𝑠𝑛\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{S}\cup\{s_{n}\}, where sn=arg​maxi∈ℛsn−1⁡Γisubscript𝑠𝑛subscriptargmax𝑖subscriptℛsubscript𝑠𝑛1subscriptΓ𝑖s_{n}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{i\in\mathcal{R}_{s_{n-1}}}\Gamma_{i}, with ℛsn−1subscriptℛsubscript𝑠𝑛1\mathcal{R}_{s_{n-1}} denoting the neighbor nodes of sn−1subscript𝑠𝑛1s_{n-1} within the 98th percentile of data dissimilarity to sn−1subscript𝑠𝑛1s_{n-1} (i.e., based on 𝚲​(0)𝚲0\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(0)). In this way, our branch algorithm relies on the GCN to decide which branch the sampling scheme will follow given its current sampled nodes (visualization in Fig. 4), so that subsequent selections are more likely to contain nodes with (i) different data distributions while (ii) leading to new neighborhoods that can contribute to the current set. Once the sampled set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is determined, the offloading is scheduled for t=0,…,T𝑡0…𝑇t=0,...,T per the solver for 𝓟Dsubscript𝓟𝐷\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D} from Sec. III.

Summary of methodology: Fig. 3 summarizes our methodology developed in Sec. III&IV for solving 𝓟𝓟\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}. The sequential convex optimization for offloading (Sec. III) is embedded within the GCN-based sampling procedure (Sec. IV). Once the model is trained on sample network realizations, it is applied to the target network to generate the 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and 𝚽​(t)𝚽𝑡\boldsymbol{\Phi}(t) for FedL.

V Experimental Evaluation

V-A Setup and Experimental Procedure

V-A1 Network characteristics via wireless testbed

We employed our IoT testbed in Fig. 5 to obtain device and communication characteristics. It consists of Jetson Nano, Coral Dev Board TPU, and UP Squared AI Edge boards configured to operate in D2D mode. We used Dstat [48] to collect the device resources and power consumption. We map the measured computing resources (in CPU cycles and RAM) and the corresponding power consumption (in mW) at devices to the costs and capacities in our model by calculating the Gateway Performance Efficiency Factor (GPEF) [38]. Specifically, to determine the processing costs pi​(t)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}(t), we measured the GPEF of the devices running gradient iterations on the MNIST dataset [49]. For the processing capacities Pi​(t)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑡P_{i}(t), we pushed the devices to 100% load and measured the GPEF. We initialized the devices at 25%-75% loads, and treated the available remaining capacity as the receive buffer parameter θi​(t)subscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}(t).

For the transmission costs, we measured GPEF spent on D2D offloading over WiFi. Our WiFi links, when only devoted to D2D offloading, consistently saturated at 12 Mbps. To simulate the effect of external tasks, we limit available bandwidth for D2D to 1, 6, and 9 Mbps. We then calculated the transmission resource budget for devices as transfer limits Ψi​(t)subscriptΨ𝑖𝑡\Psi_{i}(t), and modelled unit transfer costs ψi,j​(t)subscript𝜓𝑖𝑗𝑡\psi_{i,j}(t) as normalized D2D latency.

V-A2 Datasets and large-scale network generation

For FedL training, we use MNIST and Fashion-MNIST (F-MNIST) [50] image classification datasets. We consider a CNN predictor composed of two convolutional layers with ReLU activation and dropout. The devices perform τ=5𝜏5\tau=5 rounds of gradient descent with a learning rate η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01. Following [12], we generate network topologies with N=100𝑁100N=100 to 800800800 devices using Erdös–Rényi graphs with link formation probability (i.e., Ai,j=1subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗1A_{i,j}=1) of 0.10.10.1. To produce local datasets across the nodes that are both overlapping and non-i.i.d, the datapoints at each node are chosen uniformly at random with replacement from datapoints among three labels (i.e., image classes). Differentiating the labels between devices captures dataset heterogeneity (i.e., from different devices collecting different labels). The number of initial datapoints Di​(0)subscript𝐷𝑖0D_{i}(0) at each device follows a normal distribution with mean μ=(D𝒩​(0))​N−1𝜇subscript𝐷𝒩0superscript𝑁1\mu=(D_{\mathcal{N}}(0))N^{-1} and variance σ2=0.2​μsuperscript𝜎20.2𝜇\sigma^{2}=0.2\mu. We further estimate the initial similarity weights λi,j​(0)subscript𝜆𝑖𝑗0\lambda_{i,j}(0) based on the procedure discussed in Sec. II-B.

For the GCN-based sampling procedure, we train the model on small network realizations of ten devices. We consider sampling budgets of S=3𝑆3S=3 to 666, with thousands of training samples E𝐸E in each case. We save the resulting graph convolutional layer weights 𝐐(1)superscript𝐐1\mathbf{Q}^{(1)} and 𝐐(2)superscript𝐐2\mathbf{Q}^{(2)} for each choice of S𝑆S and reapply them on the larger target networks.

V-B Results and Discussion

In the following experiments, we compare our methodology to several baseline sampling and offloading schemes. The three sampling strategies considered are smart, random, and heuristic. Smart sampling refers to our proposed method, random sampling is done by averaging the performance over five randomly sampled combinations of devices, and heuristic sampling selects the devices with the highest processing capacities. Each of the three sampling schemes is either done without or with offloading. For smart sampling, our offloading methodology is used. For random sampling, we perform random offloading. For heuristic sampling, we perform a greedy offloading that maximizes the number of received data points for the device. A baseline of FedL with no sampling (i.e., all nodes active) and no offloading is also included.

V-B1 Model accuracy

Figs. 6 and 7 show FedL accuracy for both datasets in six different combinations (S=3,4,5𝑆345S=3,4,5 and N=100,200𝑁100200N=100,200). Overall, we see that the final accuracy obtained by our smart with (w/) offloading scheme outperforms all of the other methods except for FedL in two cases (6a&6d). The comparison with FedL all nodes is remarkable as that leverages all of the devices in the network, while the sampling uses at most 5% of them. Our smart data offloading methodology outperforms FedL due to two main reasons: (i) it minimizes data skew resulting from unbalanced label frequencies, and (ii) it ensures higher quality of local datasets at sampled nodes, which reduces bias caused by multiple local gradient descents. Without offloading, the improvement obtained over the heuristic and random sampling strategies consistently exceeds 20% for MNIST and 10% for F-MNIST, which shows that sampling optimization still leads to considerable improvements when D2D is disabled. On the other hand, our method with offloading obtains a substantial improvement over no offloading in most cases, whereas these differences are smaller for the heuristic and random methods. This emphasizes the importance of designing the sampling and offloading schemes for FedL jointly.

V-B2 Model convergence speed

We next compare the convergence speeds of our methodology to the other schemes in terms of the number of global aggregations needed to reach a certain percentage of the final accuracy of FedL with all nodes. Table I compares the convergence speeds on MNIST (to reach 85%) and F-MNIST (to reach 65%), respectively, for N=600,700,800𝑁600700800N=600,700,800 and S=6𝑆6S=6. Overall, we see that our joint sampling and offloading methodology obtains significantly faster training speeds than the other methods, on average 40% for MNIST and 50% for F-MNIST. Enabling offloading is also seen to improve the convergence speeds of each sampling scheme; in fact, without offloading, several baseline cases fail to reach the given percentage of the FedL baseline.

V-B3 Resource utilization

Finally, we compare the resource utilization for the different schemes in terms of the total data processed across nodes in the network. Fig. 8 gives the results for each dataset, comparing the datapoints processed by methods with and without offloading to reach within a percentage of an arbitrary reference accuracy (60%). We see that smart sampling (with or without offloading) outperforms the other schemes in all cases, which highlights the computational efficiency obtained by our method. As the accuracy level increases, our methodology constantly requires less datapoints compared to the other methods (on average 40% fewer), emphasizing its ability to filter out duplicate data.

These experiments demonstrate that our joint optimization method exceeds baseline performances in terms of model accuracy, convergence speed, and resource utilization.

VI Conclusion and Future Work

In this paper, we developed a novel methodology to solve the joint sampling and D2D offloading optimization problem for FedL. Our theoretical analysis of the offloading subproblem produced new convergence bounds for FedL, and led to a sequential convex optimization solver. We then developed a GCN-based algorithm that determines the sampling strategy by learning the relationships between the network properties, the offloading topology, the sampling set, and the FedL accuracy. Our implementations using real-world datasets and IoT measurements from our testbed demonstrated that our methodology obtains significant improvements in terms of datapoints processed, training speed, and resulting model accuracy compared to several other algorithms, including FedL using all devices. Future investigations will consider the integration of realistic network characteristics on FedL.

Then, (24) can be upper bounded using the definition in (1):

∥∇F(𝐰𝒮(t)|𝒟i(t))−∇F(𝐰𝒮(t)|𝒟𝒩(t))−ζ(𝐰𝒮(t))∥\displaystyle\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t))-\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t))\|
≤∥ζ(𝐰𝒮(t))∥+γDi​(t)≤∥−1D𝒩​(t)∑i∈𝒮^Di(t)∇F(𝐰𝒮(t)|𝒟i(t))\displaystyle\leq\|\zeta(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t))\|+\frac{\gamma}{\sqrt{D_{i}(t)}}\leq\Bigg{\|}\frac{-1}{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)}\sum_{i\in\hat{\mathcal{S}}}D_{i}(t)\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))
+D𝒩​(t)−D𝒮​(t)D𝒩​(t)​D𝒮​(t)​∑i∈𝒮Di​(t)​∇F​(𝐰𝒮​(t)|𝒟i​(t))∥+γDi​(t).conditionalsubscript𝐷𝒩𝑡subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝐷𝒩𝑡subscript𝐷𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡∇𝐹conditionalsubscript𝐰𝒮𝑡subscript𝒟𝑖𝑡𝛾subscript𝐷𝑖𝑡\displaystyle+\frac{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)-D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)}{D_{\mathcal{N}}(t)D_{\mathcal{S}}(t)}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}D_{i}(t)\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))\Bigg{\|}+\frac{\gamma}{\sqrt{D_{i}(t)}}. (34)

Applying the triangle inequality on the above gives the result.
